name: Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures
description: "The most rewarding game of 2013!" Influenced by retro classics Mega Man and Castlevania, Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures features the AVGN and friends as they blast their way through 10 levels of fun, fast paced 2D action based on the AVGN's adventures in his online series.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP or later Processor: Pentium 4 or higher Memory: 256 MB RAM Graphics: 256MB or higher DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 40 MB available space Sound Card: Any
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7 or 8 Memory: 1 GB RAM DirectX: Version 10

reviews.review_text: One of the most frustrating, yet fun to play platformers I've ever had the pleasure of playing. A game based on the hit, internet sensation the Angry Video Game Nerd, a character portrayed by James Rolfe whom reviews older games ranging from the Atari, to the SEGA Genesis to the NES and a bunch more.   Off the bat, the game starts out by introducing the Angry Video Game Nerd (or AVGN for short) before he is sucked into the TV (by the balls no less!) and is forced to play through what he calls hell. The stages, quotes, etc are references to older video games and episodes he has done in the past. The game itself conveys a traditional 8-Bit art style for the majority of assets used in the game aswell as play the expected 8-bit style music to go along with them.   Now, personally, I love this game and actively recommend it to everyone that loves/loved watching AVGN and likes tough platformers in general. The game plays out very similarly to classic MegaMan games and Mario Bros, since the Nerd has his standard jump, shoot and crouch, as well as a few nifty temporary power-ups you can pick up across the stages - these range from the Glitch Gremlin (a green creature that glitches the game and often helps with progression as it halts both stage hazards and enemies), the Super Mega Death Christ (Yes lol, a power up that destroys every enemy present on the screen at the time.), an upgraded gun for the Nerd (Has a much bigger hitbox than his standard light gun) and rocks (Yes rocks, like those found on one of his older episodes that he says is useless because of the low travel distance and low damage).   The game has a 3 damage health system and lives (unless you pick a higher or lower difficulty setting in which the game alters these). 3 beer bottles pretty much signal how many more hits you can take before dying, and the lives, like in older Megaman games, means how many times you can retry before being kicked out from the stages. There are also toasters (checkpoints) scattered across the stage to mark your progress on any given stage, but they are optional to activate as there are also beer bottles scattered across to help restore health to you - and there's also secret characters you can unlock all based on his show.   Stage Progression~ Generally, excluding the tutorial stage - you pick a stage in a similar fashion to MegaMan games, there are 8 in total. Each stage has their own deathtraps, some will take a point of damage, and some, like the golden skull blocks found across every stage, will kill you in one hit. Some zones are based around very careful and timing based jumps, movement, etc - like some zones will have an enemy type that is there to hinder you while you do a section, it's all very much reminiscent of the old formula of games back in the day - and like those games, this game isn't very forgiving.   In general, if you're a fan of the AVGN no doubt you'll already have this, but if you're a fan of tough NES-like platformers, get this game. From the obscenely ridiculous references to the appealing art style, this game screams AVGN charm.  B+

First off, I wanna say that even on Easy, the game is very hard, and it reaches ridiculous levels of hard in some places; Especially the final boss in my opinion, though that's probably because I don't play hard platformers all that much.   Other than that, this game gives a pretty damn good challenge, but at the same time, it really does make you wanna rage; It's basically showing you what's it like to be in a frustrating game that AVGN played, so if you're inexperienced with platformers, I'd think about it real hard before getting it, or try playing some free ones or emulated ones.  Though I do feel that the difficulty is fake at some parts. You probably can't even get through some parts without dying, and if you're just here for a fun-filled game, that kind of can hinder the enjoyability, at least in my opinion. Hoping the second one is a bit more easier.  Other than that, it's a good game.

After finally completing The Angry Video Game Adventures for the first time i can only say...WOW.  STORY: The plot of AVGN Adventures goes like this: One day the Nerd and his friends were playing a ***** game, when suddenly the TV sucks them in, the nerd tries to escape, but he gets grabbed by the sack and he enters Game Land to complete 9 levels and find out who the **** is responsible for this.   PRESENTATION: AVGN Adventures, like many other games, looks like an old retro-NES-SNES-game and by that i mean that the game has a mixture between 8 and 16 bits type graphics and sound (all tho you could argue with 32 bits for the sound, but that's besides the point). The sprites and backgrounds are well done and detailed, the framerate is consistent (at around 60fps) and the music ¡is kick-***!, everything in this game looks colorful, eye catching and different from one and other.   GAMEPLAY: AVGN Adventures plays like a 2D platforming shooter from the NES era with a very high difficulty. You platform around and shoot the enemies with the NES Zapper to progress and you can get upgrades or sub-weapons to add to your arsenal.   The game has 4 Characters to play with and each of them has some especial attribute, tho you do have to find the other characters. First there's 'The Nerd', which is my personal favorite, he's the most balanced character of them all with a decent run speed, a decent jump high and he does decent damage, BUT! he is the only character who can use the upgrades and sub-weapons + he can stand in place and shoot in 8 directions, he is personally my character of choice most of the time. Then there's the 'The Guitar Guy', he might seem like an awful character at first since he cannot use any sub-weapon or upgrade, he can only fire straight forward and he's jump is very...meh, BUT! he is the fastest of the bunch and his proyectiles can go through walls, proyectiles and barriers and believe me that doesn't sound like much, but he is very useful later on, especially on the final boss. Next there's '************ Mike', he has decent run speed and his weapon has a little range, BUT! he can use that weapon to destroy certain walls and he can jump the highest. And then theres '********-Man', he is the slowest of the bunch and he's jump is TERRIBLE, BUT he's the strongest and he can do a 'not-so-helpful-double-jump', personally i never used him, and i feel he's the worst of all the characters. You find these hidden characters (excluding the Nerd) by using the abilities that each of them have.   Now while the game does have all of those characters, they are actually not required to beat the game. YEAH every level was designed in a way so you can complete all of them with just the Nerd, but while this is true, certain parts of the levels will be a **** ton easier if you have a buddy along with you, so keep that in mind. Speaking of the levels, the level design, for the most part, is pretty good...that's all i can say about it. This is certainly good level design, but i feel like sometimes got lazy when designing some parts of the levels. Each level has some sort of gimmick in them, but aside from that each level plays pretty much the same way. One of the things that this game loves to throw you is death blocks (pretty self-explanatory), there's like a bizillion of them throughout the game and the placement can be very brutal at times. The levels have some very fun set pieces and creative enemies (tho some of them are just re-skins of other enemies).   Overall the level design for the most part is really good, but there are some parts that are designed to anger you AND OMG they succeed. The game is hard, in a Castlevania, Ninja Gaiden, Zelda II, Megaman type of way. Now don't worry it's not as hard as any of those, but some of them can make say the phrases that the nerd says every time you die. But quite frankly only 2 of the 9 levels legitimately angered me and by the 2-3-4-6-8 playthrough of the level...it wasn't that bad and i felt like most of my deaths were fair and even if you feel like you are having a hard time, the game has different difficulty levels. I recommend normal mode for your first playthrough, it gives you 30 lives and 3 beers (which are this game life bar) and even in the highest difficulty, there are a lot of checkpoints throughout each stage.   At the end of every level there's a Boss which will require a different strategy to defeat and you will have to memorize the patterns in order to beat them, tho some of them are very easy.   The game has a lot of references to the Angry Video Game Videos and any AVGN fan (like me) will feel right at home with the over abundance of references, jokes and even cameos from other youtubers and enemies of the Nerd.   So overall with great graphics, music, bosses, characters, controls, decent level design, references and much more, Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures gets and 8/10. Definitely worth your money...and i can't wait for the sequel!!!.

Since I'm a HUGE fan of the Angry Video Game Nerd, I decided to purchase this game recently. And after a few days, I'm definitely not disappointed.  The game is very reminiscent of many old NES sidescrollers, mainly Mega Man, as it uses the 'choose your level' kind of gameplay like Mega Man does. And there's also.. running while shooting a zapper like in Mega Man.. yey. It makes it rather fun to play, while being rather nostalgic at the same time, which is also added on by the 8-bit style of this game. I also like the bit of challenge within the game, as some of the levels do make you think what you need to do, and being careful in general, giving a bit of strategy.   Another thing I like is how it has references to the actual show, with the powerups like the 'Glitch Gremlin' and 'Super Mecha Death Christ 2000,' as well as having some of the characters such as Mike Matei, and even the levels do reference some of the games he's played. Not to mention, some of the things he says within the game and the cutscenes add some decent humor as well.  So, overall, It's a fun game that is definitely a good purchase if your a fan of the Angry Video Game Nerd, or even if you're not a big fan, but you like to play old NES games like Mega Man. Either way, it's still a good purchase.

If your a fan of James Rolf best known as the Angry Video Game Nerd and wanted to play this game based on his character your in luck or are you? Well this game is a very difficult and a hard platformer with obstacles that go a bit more overboard. Other than the enemies there are these things called Death Blocks touch them and you are dead. And this game has a lot of death blocks. It is a very frustrating game to play but if your good at platformers or played them before this game is relentlessly challenging. There are also hidden characters to encounter and play as and references from games that AVGN has talked about. It also has different power ups that are based off of AVGN episodes. The music is enjoyable and awesome to hear and it's funny to see all the random generated quotes after you die. A good game if you like hard platformers or a fan of the Angry Video Game Nerd.

A great NES-style side-scrolling game even if you've never played an NES side-scroller (which I haven't). It also helps a lot if you're an AVGN fan, as there are a lot of comical references scattered throughout the game.  The game is ball-bustingly hard and cuss-inducingly irritating, but in a way that makes you want to keep playing it over and over again rather than making you want to stand up and throw your computer across the room (but you might do that too). Plus, there's also the comic relief you'll get from one of many of AVGN's trademark 'I'd rather' lines, which you see every time you die.  Oh, and the music's awesome, too.

Remember the days when you use to sit in front of a 20' CRT TV playing side scrollers for hours? You do? Well then, this game is for you!  Don't think for a second that this is another rip-off of Super Mario Bros, because it's not. Be ready to get your ♥♥♥ kicked while laughing about getting your ♥♥♥ kicked. Your left thumb may even feel that old but familiar feeling of rubbing the d-pad too much. Right Pointer Finger will take his turn shooting/jumping while his best friend Mr. Thumb is having a well-deserved break. All the stuff you remember and love from retro gaming is here!  I'd hate to see how much time I wasted as a kid playing this kind of game; Steam game tracking will certainly give me a good idea in the near future. The fond memories this game pulls from the back of my mind is what makes this game so special. I have not played a game like this in years!!!  Do yourself a favor... Take a break from the HD games and play this!  Two thumbs up!

The humor is exactly what I expected from the AVGN. I don't always find it funny, and I generally enjoy Jame's videos more for the information and content than his 'angry' rants. However, this game has it's funny moments - and the cameos always made me laugh. But most importantly is that THIS GAME IS INCREDIBLE. If you play on the easiest setting, and are an experienced platform gamer, you should be able to play through it withing a couple hours of game time (if that). But then this feels like a classic 'go back, play it again, do it better, find everything, beat it on higher difficulty' style of game play.  The controls are incredible - and I use a Logitech F310, so nothing perfect, but the game feels amazing. The contoller support is wonderful, as well.  It plays in a similar manner to a Mega Man game with it's intense platforming... but it runs much faster and much more smoothly. I would honestly love to find more games that play just like this. I can't get enough of it!

I bought this game after watching a short lets play on Youtube. It seemed like a fun game based on the visuals and concept. Being a fan of the AVGN series I wanted to support that as well. But boy do I regret spending those buck.   The controls are so stiff that jumping on a platform fails in most cases. It feels like they were intentionally made stiff to subtract from the ability to steer the nerd. The truth I however fear is that the guys who made this game are inexperienced game devs or simply have no skill in their trade whatsoever OR were so busy thinking of foul words that they didn't have time to test if the game was actually playable.  The good humor from the series is more or less absent in place of just swearing endlessly. In regard to the indie AVGN fan games I've played (watch episode 115 if unsure of which I'm referring) this doens't present much original content.   The level design is really bad as well. I haven't played for that long because I more or less ragequit due to all these issues I'm adressing here. But I did play all stages. And they're the same: Unfair when they should instead be challenging. I've played and beaten tons of platform games. Especially old and hard ones. But this simply isn't fun.  I wish there were more positive things to say about this. Unpolished, frustrating, insulting and unworthy of my time.  To sum it up: FreakZone Games did an awful job with this game, and why ScrewAttack would have them make a sequel is beyond my comprehension.

READ ENTIRE REVIEW BEFORE DECIDING UPON IT!  'He's gonna take you back to past...'  AVGN Adventures is a 2D sidescroller platformer inspired by alot of retro classics...and alot of retro disasters, but we'll talk about that later. Anyway, you should know who the Angry Video Game Nerd is. He single handedly started everything to do with gaming videos online. He's a foulmouth nerd who has dedicated his life to warning the world of bad games, whilst being absolutley hilarious at the same time. If you have never watched him, what are you waiting for> Go watch an episode right now 'cause you're really missing out.  Anyway, the game starts the Nerd being sucked into one of these terrible games and must get ou. Simple, right? Ladies and Gentlemen, I now present to you my least favrioute thing about this game...  THE DIFFICULTY IS OFF THE CHARTS!!!  I never usually loose my temper with games. However this one really started bugging me within 5 mins of boot up. Not trying to spoil anything, but I was in sweat and tears during the final boss fight. I tried for an hour and couldn't do it. I managed to develop a stratergy for part of the fight, but died something like 400 times. I gave up all red and in tears. The next night I went back and my strategy still worked, but I was still struggling. So I used a walkthrough, combined it with my stratergy and I finnaly did it!  Anyway, the point is this is easily the hardest game I've ever played. Even on easy. I'm impressed just beating it once on easy only having to use a walkthrough once!  But, the real problem here...  If you watched AVGN for as long as I have, you probably will have memorised some of the things he complains about in games. And, without listing them, I can tell you this game has ALOT of these problems. Its like it took inspiration from bad games!   WHAT WERE THEY THINKING?!  (Sigh...)I usually decide whether I'll reccomend or not reccomend a game beofre reviewing, but this time I'm really struggling. This game almost ruined AVGN for me. I went through sweat and tears just to beat this game on the easiest difficulty! However, it has gogeous retre graphics, occasinally fun gameplay and, of course, the Nerd. If you're into challenging platformers (e.g. Megaman, Castlevania and Mario), this is one to look out for. The graphics are pretty sweet and the music is awesome. The control is good and unique in its way, comparable to Mario, but slightly stiffer. Be warned for very frustrating level design. Fortunately, there are many many checkpoints on the way and you get 30 lives to start with. That should give you a good idea of how this game is designed and I like it a lot.  The reason for not recommending this game is because of technical issues. This game does not play well on a keyboard so I highly recommend using a controller, but besides the Xbox 360-controller, getting standard Windows controllers up and running is way too hard to do and required the use of third-party software, plus there's a bug that introduces 8 seconds load time after every death when using the controller, which is horendous. These are issues that were mentioned a lot in the forums, so I am not the only one. As such, even though the game is fun and creative, I cannot recommend a game that is technically underdeveloped. I have tested version 1.7.1 from february 2014.   Other than that, this game begs to be played on a tv with a controller in your hand, rather than on a PC. I would like to encourage the developers to make it run natively under SteamOS. This is one of those games that would benefit from an open console platform.

It's good, worth a couple dollars no more. I've been watching AVGN for a long time now, and this game is very suiting. But don't pay too much; to won't be worth your investment. Catch this game on sale if you can. This is the short answer. If you want to know more read on.  The good:  The controls are good, though definitely use a controller. A keyboard has felt clumsy for me and the developers definitely had using a playstation or xbox controller in mind.   The story is VERY AVGN. It's a bit of fun and makes it worth playing for a while. If you've watched AVGN a lot, you'll see a lot of references to his videos throughout the game. The humor is funny for a little while, but it gets a bit tiresome.   The music is great. Every stage has different theme and it's some of the best 8-bit music out there. The sound effects make it sound like your zapper or sound waves are really inflicting quite a bit of damage on the enemies you hit. These are great compliments to the game.  The difficulty is quite hard, but once you get used to the controls, you'll be blaming yourself rather than the game for deaths. The first few stages aren't terribly difficult in comparison with the later stages (they'll give you a run for your money though), but the later ones aren't nearly so easy. More on that later.  I haven't had any major gripes with the types of enemies.  The eh:  The stages get very repetitive and by the end, you don't feel like you're really playing a different stage with completely new enemies. Most of the enemies are reskins from other levels. For example, the fireballs, the happy faces, the flying ghosts, the squids are all the same, just different shapes. These are the most common enemies, and you can't even kill them. Furthermore, there aren't enough enemies for the diversity of weapons. So many times have I wanted to slaughter a band of enemies with my light saber but rarely do any come. And the ones that do come are so difficult to hit, it's easier to just avoid them than to risk getting hurt by one.  The extra characters are cool, but they're usually impractical to use. The guitar guy has a better weapon, but he can't aim it and he can't jump as high as the Nerd. It's too bad there aren't quite that many enemies that can be killed. Mike jumps higher than the nerd, but he's a bit clumsier and his weapon isn't nearly as good as either of the others (kind of like Luigi in the recent 3D Marios). The ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t man gets a special second jump, but even with both jumps he still can't jump higher than the Nerd. His weapon sucks, don't use it. There aren't really any points in the game where you realize you HAVE to use another character. It's a shame because this could have been a real good opportunity for a bit of a puzzle design.  Powerups are in the game, but they're too scant to be useful. Plus sometimes they don't even do anything good anyway! The glitch gremlin will stop all enemy movement, but what good does it do if you have standstill ghosts everywhere and there's no way to jump over them all? It's impossible to freeze them at the perfect time.  The later stages are just tedious. Multiple obstacles face you in every direction and the game isn't even fair for most of them. For example, the haunted stage involves moving platforms that you have to keep up with. But if you haven't played that part of the stage before, you're bound to fall off because of the unpredictable motions of the platform. I understand a couple deaths to this, but the coupling of the platforms, enemies, and those wretched death blocks make the game outright frustrating.  In fact, my biggest gripe has got to be the death blocks. The death blocks are everywhere and they don't add to the game experience. If you touch them, you'll die instantaenously; it doesn't matter how many beers you have left. With so many in the game, you will come to realize that there's no reason to avoid the other flying enemies since your main obstacle are those death blocks. The death blocks are strategically placed in stupid locations designed to make you die and start all over again. They just seem like cheap deaths. With so many death blocks around, it's nearly impossible to beat the game on normal difficulty, let alone hard.  The humor feels much much darker than the Nerd is in his videos. Maybe it's the open-mouthed shock-face that James instills in his character every time something goes horribly wrong that the game developers didn't manage to recreate in-game. The nerd starts dissing the game too early and never stops.  Conclusion:  If you're a fan of the Nerd, get this game under one condition: don't buy this game for more than $7! The game gets a couple things perfectly right but then forgets or gets too lazy to change it up. If the developers didn't want to spend the extra time to program new and intuitive enemies, better levels, and more exciting uses of your teammates, you shouldn't pay the extra money to buy this game.

A really fun throw back to the games I used to love playing in the 8-bit days. It is fairly short and can be incredibly frustrating, but a blast at the same time. I loved this game but would only recommend it on two conditions, the first is that you enjoy old style games that can be frustrating and that you are not easily offended by cursing, poop jokes, and weird 8-bit style nudity.

PROS: The game's 2D feel definitely comes out like a classic game. The controls are tight, and the music is just wonderful, fitting for each zone.  CONS: The game feels very cheap, and it fails to improve on some of the things people wanted to forget from classic games. Knock back is a major problem, as everything will shove you back. Enemy placement isn't a problem, but the over reliance on instant death blocks makes some parts an absolute joke until trial and error kicks in. And although the harder difficulties are there for the challenge, YOLO mode is made to be quite the horror thanks to the problems.  ACHIEVEMENTS: The difficulty will cause a long and extended frustration.  FINAL: The game is well put together, however, the over reliance of annoying and cheap tricks used in the NES brings about it's failure to push the game to a standard of higher quality. Instead of becoming a game to poke fun and improve the formula, it falls squarely into place. A solid title, but one that could have been a great deal better.

This is a piece taken directly from Screwattack homepage: Some say 'hard,' but we're saying 'rewarding!' Why? Even if you're not into AVGN, the game is pretty enjoyable. However while it tries to be unfair to stay on character and retro, there're severe difficulty spikes once in a while. You might find very rough obstacles and various trial and error challenges, while in others you will face simpler counterparts. This is specially the case on the last stage, where you encounter a part with bouncy platforms which a previous stage made much harder to pass through. This is not exactly a big flaw, but is highly recommended to play first with infinite lifes and then try the other modes once you figure out the stages.  However there are are few things i really didn't like. There's a severe abuse of instadeath blocks, and while that makes the point of AVGN nature and behavior, is more about lack of obstacles graphically, as in some stages uses lasers but others goes with columns of death blocks acting the same way. Another thing is that in some segments there's too much noise on screen, and combined with the soundtrack can be hard to concentrate.  AVGN Adventures is not the perfect game, but behind that bag of references and trash humor there's a solid game for an hour or two of gameplay.

AVGN has been apart of internet culture for quite some time now, so it was a no brainer that the nerd would finally get his own game.  The AVGN is notorious for playing bad games and being rather crude while presenting such games. What I find interesting about the AVGN game is that they actually incorporated these game design flaws and made them into something great. From impossible jumps to unfair design, AVGN Adventures takes these monstrosities of game design and turns it into something fresh, exciting and just fun.  The difficulty on this one is worthy of the title 'NES Hard' and the actual game itself plays like a mixture between the original classic Mega Man games and Contra. The music is reminiscient of nostalgic 80s chip tune and brings gamers back to a time where the basics were all you needed. The sprite art is beautifully built from the ground up with some clear inspiration from other titles, again, such as Mega Man.  Many people seem to say that this game has hardly any replay value which I would like to say is complete bogus. There are three different characters to play as in AVGNA, two of which need to be unlocked by finding them hidden throughout the 8 different stages (All based on episodes of the AVGN.) Also, the game can be played in different difficulty settings, allowing for more than one gameplay experience. A true completionist will want to not only beat this game in more than one way, but master AVGNA, much like those of retro gaming tastes do.  The in game dialogue (in text boxes) is crude, filthy, disgusting, and downright hilarious. AVGNA incorporates many of the Nerds' iconic quotes as well as invent new terms that are definetly NSFW.  Overall, this game is definetly worth purchasing and playing through. The difficulty is extreme at times and I would recommend a controller rather than a keyboard. Those with a taste for retro gaming will find this a masterpiece. Even, if you're not into retro gaming, pick this one up when it goes on sale. You won't regret it.

In the barest of descriptions, this game is a piece of interactive fan-art. It distills 8+ years of content from it’s legacy, The Angry Video Game Nerd (produced by James Rolfe, who is a pretty awesome guy) into a Nintendo-length and Nintendo-hard adventure. For those who have watched the web-series, it’s a short walk down memory lane, a challenge to find all the references and easter eggs, and a way to experience the trials The Nerd has experienced over the lifespan of the series. It was lovingly produced to be an intentional experience, and for fans, it’s delightful.  It’s important to point out that this game is not for everyone. Like most fan-art, you can appreciate the aesthetics if you approach it unaware of the original work, but a lot of the heart, depth and meaning will be lost. Yes, the “retro” graphics are charming and the game handles well, and you may even see inspirations in the level design from games like Castlevania if that’s your generation. However, with no other perspective, you will soon be frustrated by the games seemingly poor level design. The game constantly cheats and frustrates you, killing you time and time again at no real fault of your own. Things appear skewed against you in some very unfair and unfun ways, never relenting.  For fans of the series, however, this is expected. This game emulates the experiences of The Nerd throughout the video series, constantly subjecting himself to terrible games from the genesis of home gaming under the premise of warning others against their trespasses. This game takes a sampling of those horrors and concentrates them into one experience, each level its own little snapshot of gaming hell. The joy of playing this game is largely derived from nostalgia, remembering the Olde Games and the despicable things that they did to you, that they made you do to beat them. We remember afternoons and evenings spent dedicated to conquering just one more level, despite the awful controls, the contrived traps and the straight-up horrendous level design. It’s all we had, and we didn't know better. This was just the way games were. We hated them, but we kept coming back, learning to love them like digital Stockholme-suffering prisoners.  Conceptually, the game helps us remember simpler times, and for that I do recommend it, but with a caveat: If you aren't from the Nintendo generation, or you haven’t seen the Angry Video Game Nerd web series, then I highly suggest you experience those things first.

This game is done in classic 8bit style, but has the more refined controls of a 16bit game. That being said, get ready for th insane amount of difficulty that comes from those types of games.  Much of the game revolves memorizing certain patterns of the of the enemies of whatever world you're in, and this means that there will be a lot of dying. But, the game is incredibly fair with lives and check points, so you have no true reason to stop trying.  But if you're not a fan of his most, if not all the references will fly straight over your head.  In all, it's a great platformer, in that old symplistic style, but but people unaware of the character it's based on won't uderstand many of the jokes.  7.5/10

6/10  I hesitate to “recommend” the game but I can’t let myself give it a bad review. If you enjoyed the platformers of old (NES specifically) you will find some familiar tropes and humor. I’ve never really watched anything this game is based on – I was more interested in the throwback style and references to old games. The game itself is fun but challenging to a fault – it’s nearly unplayable except with the unlimited lives option. The levels are designed to be a throwback to the challenging platformers of old but they go too far and create something that is borderline unplayable. I’ve actually beaten Battletoads and Ghost and Goblins on their respective systems and this game is harder than either of those combined.

Well, they finally did it.   I wasn't too familiar with the AVGN until recently, when I marathoned episodes after attending James' panel at SGC.  This game hits it.  Though it'd really suck if it hadn't, considering the amount of attention that ScrewAttack and other related dudes paid to it during development.  Tight controls, vintage level design, and (of course) 'Nerd allusions define this game. With a gamepad, it feels like I'm playing a SNES game that's been inexplicably ported to XBLA, and that's a  damn good thing . But if you're not accustomed to the kind of language and imagery that's an integral part of the show, it can seem a bit overwhelming.  (here's a tip: don't die)   That said, it's a definite must-have for fans of ScrewAttack, AVGN, and the classics alike.

Oh my God this game... let me just say that I was brought up with the N64 as a kid so 8-Bit side scrollers such as this weren't really known to me until only a few years ago, but this game was awesome. I watched the AVGN episodes regliously for a few years and this game most definitly does the series justice. The game mirrors the comedy that fans and viewers of the show are familiar with and honestly really well done.  Graphically speaking ... yes it is pixelated but thats the style and I found it quite gorgeous both everything in the foreground as well as the backround. The different levels have there own unique environment that is loaded with the color and atmostpheric look of the game it is trying to mimic.   The sound track is simply awesome ive played a little over 3 hours and it has yet to be boring to me. Also i found it quite helpful in executing platforming that required precise timing.  The challenge element of this game is incredible and lives up the the games of the 8-bit era. your given 30 lives and ive found myslef burning through at least half of them on one stage (this could be because im not especially good in 2D platformers). I would definitly compare the challenge to that of Mega Man... yes it is a difficult game even on a normal setting but practice makes perfect and after playing for a while I did definitly see improvement in my own abilities. The learning curve is perfect and it provides just the right amount of challenge. Since starting to play, ive only be able to complete 4 of the total stages.  All in all if your a fan of a good challenge, the web series or even classical platformers this is a must have.

When I heard that Steam was selling a game starring James Rolfe the AVGN himself, I didn't know what to think. Personally, I'm more of an Irate Gamer fan (haters please don't spam me a bunch of hate), but since I still do in fact like the AVGN, I decided to check out the game. After playing it, I was amazed. The game takes inspiration from classics such as Mega Man and Castlevania. The graphics, music, nostalgic values, gameplay, humor and replay value were just remarkable. Even if you don't like the AVGN or his videos, I still recommend this game, because its a great stand alone game, even without the AVGN character. My only nitpick with the game is that there are only 10 levels, but the game resembles an NES game, so I'll let that slide. I see myself playing this game a lot in the future, and I won't regret it either. Now if we could only get the Irate Gamer game on Steam, then I would have a match made in Heaven. Thanks for reading this review. Check the game out and decide for yourself :)

I am a big fan of the megaman series, castlevenia series, etc. as well as a fan of AVGN. My only issue with this game is the lives system. Why does normal difficulty limit you to a certain number of lives? There is a lot of trial-and-error gameplay (especially in the haunted house level). I like games like super meat boy which have some trial and error, but there you get unlimited lives. I think these two things should always go together. The easy setting lets you blast through the level and tank tons of hits. I wish there was a setting where you had 3 HP, but unlimited lives.
Excellent challenge and outstanding sound track. 2-D side scrolling with near perfect controls.

It's crazy hard, but the number of lives they give you and the frequent checkpoints are just right to get your adrenaline up but still make you feel like a champ. I thought 30 lives was silly, but you need a lot, and if it was infinite, your addrenaline and sense of accomplishment wouldn't be nearly so high. The physics engine is solid (not to be underappriciated), and the music is amazing. If you aren't familiar with the web video series this is based off of, you should check that out (cause if you are reading this you probably like these old school games). But, regardless of if you care about the web series, this game stands on it's own as being stellar. Even if you don't care for the comedy or references, this game is still amazing. I am a fan of the series, and I appriciate those things, but it's the gameplay that keeps me playing. Amazing job. Although there's parts of the game I hate (I'm just over half way through, I'll probably get really frustrated on the last level), I can't think of anything that would make this game better. Normally I can. Not enough good things to say about this.

Its only fitting that he gets his own game to complain about. With fantastic level design and bosses, this game is probably the best the AVGN has ever played- Don't forget the music. It's a good example of NES hard (at least on old school it is) Which contrary to some belief, difficult can actually mean better gameplay (That is for those Veteran gamers out there) I think its best not to make some games too easy on the normal difficulty setting, but have an easygoing difficulty for any newcomers, that is to allow people to get into the game easier. The AVGN Adventures is a platformer that has a good difficulty setting, an easy mode to compensate, and brilliant level design to make things even harder.
